svg.text: Azure Landing Zone â€” GitHub Actions OIDC Complete Guide
One-Time Setup â†’ Token Lifecycle â†’ Terraform Deployment
SECTION 1: One-Time Setup (Run Once Per Environment)
ğŸ“… When To Run This Script
â€¢ Once when setting up a new project
â€¢ Once per environment (dev, test, prod)
â€¢ When adding a new repo to existing infra
âš ï¸ NOT every deployment â€” just initial setup
GitHub signs tokens with private key
Azure verifies with GitHub's public key
Azure service account for your pipeline
Trust link: "GitHub repo X â†’ this identity"
âš ï¸ IMPORTANT: Dev and Prod are completely isolated â€” different subscriptions, different identities, different permissions. Dev pipeline CANNOT access Prod.
SECTION 2: Token Lifecycle (Happens Every Pipeline Run)
â€¢ Generated fresh each workflow run
â€¢ Only used to GET Azure token
If job runs >1 hour, azure/login action auto-refreshes the token. No manual intervention needed.
ğŸ“ backend.tf â€” State Storage Config
SECTION 4: Complete Architecture â€” How It All Fits Together
1. Workflow runs with environment: dev (or prod)
2. GitHub generates OIDC token with matching subject claim
3. Azure validates and returns bearer token
4. Terraform uses token to deploy to correct subscription
â–¡ Run script for dev environment
â–¡ Run script for prod environment
â–¡ Add backend.tf to your Terraform code
â–¡ Push and watch the magic happen
â†’ environment: in workflow must match -e flag
â†’ Identity not in security group, or wrong subscription
â†’ use_azuread_auth = true missing in backend
BC Government Public Cloud â€” Azure Landing Zone â€” OIDC Authentication Guide
